ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: How to think about philosophical texts and compare their approaches to different themes and concepts.
I learned the best way to approach a philosophy paper and how to consider philosophical arguments methodically.
An overview on fundamental texts in western philosophy. Analysis of difficult texts thought writing.
I learned a lot about the history of early modern and modern philosophy, while also developing my ability to discuss and write about philosophical ideas at a higher level.
analytical writing, thinking and talking about philosophy
much better understanding of classical philosophy and sem. 1 work after taking this
I developed a general understanding of modern philosophy since Descartes.
I learned how to make presentations and how to present them in a thought-provoking manner. I also learned how to read and interpret philosophical texts and make philosophical arguments.
introductory-level knowledge of notable thinkers in modern philosophy

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The seminar format was extremely helpful in fostering productive conversation.
None!

Strengths: DS Philosophy provides a nice overview of the western philosophical tradition that can be helpful in many ways. Mark is a good instructor who Leads the discussion well. His office hours are also helpful. Weaknesses: because this class is intended as a first philosophy class, some issues arent addressed as deeply and that could be frustrating in some cases. I also wish there could be more instructions on writing. It seems that learning about philosophy and writing about it are two quite different things. Knowing all the concepts doesnt necessarily mean that your writing will be as good and clear as your undertaking, so some additional trainings on writing would be helpful.

The level of discussion in the seminars was great, and I think that the presentation element that the classes had was really engaging and allowed me to gain a deeper understanding of the texts through this type of detailed explanation. The syllabus was varied and fascinating as well. One thing is that I wish we had gotten a bit more guidance in terms of what was being looked for in the essays.
it was incredible course and Professor maxwell is a great teacher

I enjoyed the course on the whole; I think teaching us to engage critically, beyond simple understanding, with the texts would be helpful. I understand that the time we have to do so is an issue, though.
The strengths of this course are that this course provides for an opportunity to learn about philosophy with the close help of a professor.

This was a great course, and Professor Maxwell was a super-engaged teacher who always brought a lot of enthusiasm to seminar. Hes genuinely excited to hear students ideas and interact with them, which I really appreciate. If there are any weakness in the course, I would say they could be fixed by Professor Maxwell being slightly more rigorous in his critiques if students arguments and structuring the topics covered in seminar more explicitly.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I wish it was in person. I also wish there could have been more social elements.

I think that the virtual seminars were great, especially because of the presentations given in-class. I would say that the recorded lectures weren't that helpful in terms of comprehension and attention span.
I think the recorded lectures werent very engaging, breakout rooms were great and the weekly presentations were also a great way to dive deeper into a specific philosopher and hear from classmates
I thought the presentations were a good way to introduce some variety and personal engagement to the class.
I think in this course it felt like the discussion format helped the class be more engaging given that it was online.
Plenty of open discussion encouraged; at times felt like an in-person course

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It was a bit fast-paced but it covered a lot of relevant philosophy, so yes!
Yes I loved it !
Yes! DS Philosophy is great. Mark is also a good instructor and very nice to talk to.

I would recommend this course to a student who wants a crash course on complex philosophical ideas by many of the most relevant thinkers from the past centuries  it is a lot of work and covers a lot of topics that are difficult to understand, but overall the seminar format really helped my comprehension and I ended the course feeling like I had learned a lot.
absolutely - DS is an incredible and unique program and Professor maxwell is very supportive and engaging.
yes!
I think DS Philosophy in the spring is good to get an overview of topics in philosophy but didn't really help me engage with any of the philosophers or feel much passion about the material.
I would recommend this course to a student that is interesting in learning fundamental philosophical concepts.
Yes, I enjoyed it very much

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: None
Recorded weekly lectures
recorded lectures
recorded lecture
We had twice-weekly seminars, presentations, readings, papers, and lectures.
N/A
recorded lecture
